reviews.title: Church Street, Toronto, Canada
text: It's quite a long street. It's famous for some celebrations. For instance, I ended up there to celebrate Halloween with my friends wearing some costumes.

reviews.title: Church street is a long street but not a great one
text: Church street is a long street but not a great one. It has many shops, including bars and restaurants and the like, but it looks old and downtrodden in  parts. People have made attempts to beautify it but it needs more work. It is not really a great pleasure to take a walk in. Perhaps another time might be better, but that was not the case when we visited.

reviews.title: Good food
text: This may not be the nicest street in Toronto, especially considering the particularly dominant sexuality of the neighborhood, but my visitation was ok. I stayed at Gloucester street which is connected to the Church Street, so I went along with the street multiple times during my stay in Toronto. However, nothing was intimidating, but rather, I was able to enjoy some affordable foods.

reviews.title: Ick
text: Desolate, unfriendly hole, full of mostly unattractive, down-and-out White Trash, who happen to be gay.  One would have expected a little arts and culture in such a neighbourhood, but just untalented Canadian nobodies, here, living in really dumpy apartment buildings run by such outfits as Greenwin, Cap Reit and (yecccchhh!) Akelius.  A blight on Toronto.  SHAME!!!

reviews.title: VERY BUSY STREET
text: A very busy street packed with a substantial number of shops and many food outlets. There are many really good restaurants and cafes in easy reach.

reviews.title: Church St.
text: Not a safe space for Christians, bigots and intolerance everywhere. Seems they really fear God here.

reviews.title: Terrific!
text: Came here with my non-binary teen.  They immediately felt completely at home. From the bookstore to shops to eateries all designed to serve the LGBT community, this was a really important part of our trip.

reviews.title: Church St
text: Fun bars/restaurants in the "Village" - I have been going to Salon One Hair Salon for years - great team

reviews.title: Mr
text: I was pleasantly surprised by this restaurant, even though it was extremely busy the service was excellent and I will tell you without any reservations that the food was great,as a matter of fact I enjoyed it so much that I actually went back the next day with the same result. If you are looking for a great atmosphere and good food this place is a must try.

reviews.title: Great Vibes
text: Church Street and the Gay Village are fabulous!  Delicious restaurants and outdoor cafes.  Just an all around good vibe.  Loved it.

reviews.title: Friendly corner of Toronto
text: People are friendly and welcoming, variety of great bars and restaurants, many with outdoor patios, great people-watching.

reviews.title: Lots of Excitement
text: Lots of exciting stuff to do in church street never boring, there a lot of shopping stores to visit and a huge amount of food eateries, nice to go with the family and make a day of it.

reviews.title: Cute Neighborhood in Toronto
text: Nice area in Toronto, close to financial district, cute bars, night life and local shops.  One of the funnest gay area's I have been to

reviews.title: Very fun, safe & friendly neighbourhood
text: My husband and I walked through this neighbourhood a few times and visited a couple of the shops, and found it to be a very friendly and safe area of the city.

reviews.title: Fun Neighbourhood!
text: Awesome area to hang out, grab a meal or drink, see a drag show, shoot some pool, dance, people watch, have an ice cream or shop. Great vibe, friendly and chill.
You will have a great time if you are gay or straight! The bars are super fun.

reviews.title: Proud of this hood
text: Affectionaly known as the Gaybourhood.  Lovely downtown street with a friendly casual neighbourhood feeling.  Many restaurants and bars, lively at night, but all serving mediocre food and expensive drinks.  Not much else in the way of shopping but you can do OK if food is your main objective.  The big fancy Loblaws is on this strip.  Interesting architecture nicely preserved.  Nice thing is families, singles, Gays, straights all live side in (mostly) harmony.  The street is hopping during the week of Pride, late June.  Closed to vehicle traffic, the hood becomes a party zone, attracting visitors from all over the world. Parades, beer gardens, other events.....Oh My!

reviews.title: Boring Gay Village
text: Mostly ordinary gay bars with moderate restaurants, nothing to write home about, most of the people look destitute. but the place is busy Thursdays to Sunday with  the usual clones

reviews.title: one of my most favorite buildings in Toronto
text: In late May 2015 I walked slowly from Younge and Bloor to Church Street and discovered several additions to the urban landscape. I had been there before especially to visit the Italian national tourist office once located in the red building near Bloor and Church. Somebody authorized the construction of a huge humongous extra tall tower of a building of a condominiums and what-have-you at Younge Street. ThIs project brings ugliness to the urban landscape again in the form of more expensive living spaced for people who want go to be downtown. Several older smaller buildings have been removed like the Green Mango to make too for this monstrosity of a building. If this is beautification for the city I question your wisdom for allowing this to happen. I think it is more like greed for developers. Now I found many visits ago too Church Street a red like building with an unusual shape and configuration near Hayden Street and Church very close to Bloor. In fact it is on Bloor but facing in a awkward direction away from having its front entrance on Bloor. Its color has been a rusty cherry like version of red and I like it very much. I have sat inside on the first floor or lobby looking outside admiring the interior design of the building. The exterior design is what brings me here. It sits in a way that makes me think that somebody misallocated the references for having the building face Bloor square ahead. It seems to out of position like when nobody was looking it moved itself around to a different angle for facing Bloor. This structure is among my favorite large buildings in this city. I have walked or travelled along Church southward in the direction of the Maitland area to find a central YMCA and several parts of ethnic neighborhoods not exceedingly large but there they were to see. This area is so different from what can be seen near Young and Bloor and Church. But it is the large tall red building on Bloor that brings me back to this corner every time I come to Toronto. I began wondering the first time I saw this red building many things. Did somebody make a mistake in the placement of the building? Who design it? Did they get what they asked for? Why is the building facing Bloor in this odd angle? There is a Sunset Grill and Loblaw food stood near by plus the metro station. Parking places inside the buildings abound. Looking at this red building from Bloor is a way for making my appreciation for urban architecture take on different level of growth. That only goes so far as the surrounding urban landscape along Bloor is being changed with the construction of condominiums and office buildings to the detriment of downtown Toronto in my opinion. Clogging up the streets with more places for people to live is one thing but giving the neighborhoods more people to deal with is another one. So much of downtown Toronto is being changed in this way. I ask you to visit the tall red building at Bloor and Church and go inside to see the interior design - the same color red brick is there to be admired. Sit on the benches inside and watch people pass by going to the elevators and the vegetation grow in the spaces outside. I have red parts of the newspaper there just to find an excuse to stay there.You should do the same. Then go outside and admire the red structure of the entire building. For me this is urban architecture at is finest. If I need an extra reason to walk along Bloor eastward fromYoung here it is. Do the same!

reviews.title: Church Street
text: This is a nice street in Toronto which lives up to it's name as there are very many  Churches along it's length. There are also some interesting neighbourhoods along it's length.  Worth visiting!

reviews.title: Super friendly, fun neighbourhood
text: I have lived in this neighbourhood, and just love it. I find it to be such a friendly and fun neighbourhood for people of all kinds, with a lot of great restaurants, some shops (including chains like David's Tea and the Body Shop), and really fun bars with great music (north of Church and Carlton). World Pride 2014 was an incredibly fun time here last summer as well. I wouldn't consider this a must-see, but if you're in the area, it's a cool place to check out and walk around, especially near Church and Wellesley.

reviews.title: Church Street Has a Colourful and Ecclectic Vibe
text: There are many wonderful local restuarants, bars and cafe's down the Church Street corridore. It's also a wonderful place for people watching. The bright rainbow coloured flags and markings up and down the street give a a friendly atmosphere to this strip of Toronto. It's a pleaant place to go for a walk.

reviews.title: Most Exciting!
text: Toronto's Church Street is the most exciting place in the city!  I personally could not believe the vibrance, ever great hospitality and friendliness of everyone! Well done guys, well done! Tons of GAY bars all over! Totally entertaining and very safe! Woody's would be my be recommendation for some what an earlier (11pm-1am) cocktail.

reviews.title: Nice friendly corner of Toronto
text: Church St is a nice vibrant street with big sidewalks. Being the gay village, its very colorful. Almost anywhere you look you will see a rainbow flag draped somewhere.

I visited the store "Out on the Street" which carried an impressive collection of men's clothing and underwear, they carry a lot of great brands, This is a necessary stop for anyone who considers themselves a clothing or underwear affictionato. Great coffee and baked good just down the street at Church Street Espresso.

reviews.title: Gay Ol Time
text: We were here during pride, so of course it was a fun, charged, festive atmosphere.  But the street parties were very well organized.  No cover to get into any of the bars!  Cool little shops, good little cafes and eateries, and most importantly, super friendly people!

reviews.title: Friendly, Welcoming Gay District
text: Church Stret is a great neighborhood in Toronto! The neighbors are very friendly & helpful. Twice we stopped to check our GPS & each time, someone stopped to see if they could help! Wonderful people!!

reviews.title: Great neighborhood
text: Rainbow neighborhood with something for anyone just wanting to enjoy the day or an evening. Coffee shops, restaurants, window shopping, people watching. Cool place to just spend some time & relax.

reviews.title: Great Place
text: Extra large rainbow sidewalks!  Fun places to eat, though many of them close earlier than I had wished. I stayed 4 nights in this neighborhood (on foot), first time in Toronto, and had a blast.

reviews.title: Friendly, Alternative and Unique
text: This area is absolutely amazing for anyone regardless of age, sex or orientation! So many nice bars , restaraunts and things too see any time of the year ! The people here are always so friendly and this area has the most friendliest service I have encountered in Toronto at least that is for sure ! A must visit for anyone ! Always something happening here any day during the week . I personally love the drag queen shows that can be found at a variety of clubs and bars here ! Must visit Woodys and Crews and Tangos !

reviews.title: Still the place, but a few losses
text: I still love Church Street, particularly the four- or five-block strip identified as part of "Church-Wellesley Village" (i.e., the gay nabe). About a month ago, however, I was disappointed to find that two of my favorite hangouts -- Daybreak Restaurant and Timothy's World Coffees -- have closed, presumably due to rising rents!

For good coffee in the area, there's The Second Cup, a block or two closer to Wellesley. If anything, the coffee's even better than Timothy's (it's hard for me to admit that), and there's comfortable seating in the rear, "upstairs" alcove. On the minus side, the location is less good for people-watching, particularly from the comfortable area.

Daybreak, however, is a real loss for breakfast hunters, especially since The Studio (diner) on Church closed about five years ago. Where do people go for breakfast in the area now? Cora's is fine, but too tourist-oriented. Fran's, over on College off Yonge, is good as diners go. But I'm looking for a real "breakfast place"!

reviews.title: A Great to Visit for Gay Culture in Canada
text: It a place where you can feel comfortable and safe. Lots of places to eat and shop and dance the night away.

They have some great patios. Great bars to drink at and lots of entertainment during the week and weekends. A must place to visit if you are traveling from a country that dose not except the gay culture.

reviews.title: Not Particularly Interesting...
text: I walked along this street on a Saturday evening. There isn’t much on this street other than the gay village which is further north of downtown Toronto, and has some restaurants and clubs on either side. I’ve heard that it’s sketchy and dangerous at night, so when it got dark, I walked alongside Yonge instead.

reviews.title: I think it's cute!
text: I am no newcomer to Gayborhoods. I love gayborhoods! Church St feels to me like a very little gayborhood and also I find it very caché and big. Not sure why. There are your common gay pubs, some more fashionable cafes and bars. The normal pizza place and the community center, the gay sauna, the gay coffe shop, the gay souvenir store. Everything is there for a lgbttti traveler. I found it very safe and fun. And I also wish it to be bigger and gayer! I was there for pride week and month and was so happy to see so many rainbow flags! I have never ever seen so many rainbows in my life!

reviews.title: Safe, friendly and beautiful.
text: I stayed in this neighborhood for two nights and I loved it. I was a woman travelling alone and I felt completely safe walking around at night. People were helpful and kind.

reviews.title: Squalid and scary
text: A very run down area. Lots of homeless and people with mental health issues on the streets. Discarded needles in the parks. Only a handful of decent shops but would not be surprised if they close soon and move out of the area. A great disappointment for a gay village. The worse gay neighbourhood I have visited. Awful shame.

reviews.title: Definitely what it used to be :(
text: After a few years I decided to come back with a few friends to the Church/Wellesley area for a night out. There was no Byzantium, no Slack Alice, No Zelda's, etc, etc, etc. All the places we entered were sad looking with NO atmosphere. No gay men anymore, but tons of straight young girls.  Some of the places we tried we did an "in and out"... They  had very loud drag queen shows screaming for attention, even Woody's! we couldn't stay in any of them.  Sadly everything looked cheap and run down. We also noticed a lot of the stores have disappeared to be replaced by a bunch of fast food joints. The only places more ore less OK were "The Drink" 459 Church (good music), The Hair of the Dog (good selection of wines & beers) and "The Churchmouse: A Firkin Pub" (passable food).   On our way back the taxi driver told us gay men don't frequent this area anymore. That hangout at The Drake, The Thompson.... and many other places East or West of downtown.   Geez!!!... I wish we knew this before... so much time wasted

reviews.title: Squalid and Dangerous...
text: Sadly this area has become squalid and dangerous. Violence and antisocial behavior have become a daily if not an hourly occurrence. The area is awash with homeless, drug addicts and people newly released from prison. Whilst they have their own stories and challenges it is not making for a pleasant or safe area.
The streets are dirty - strewn with urine, faeces and other fluids that only seemed to get a measly wash when the next rain comes.
Under no circumstances wonder into or close to the local park at night. They are very dangerous.
The 1 star awarded is for the few establishments that provide an otherwise professional business in an otherwise shabby part of town.

reviews.title: Really turning into a dive
text: I love going to gay bars and pubs. I love the nightlife and the boozy drinks.
Truth be told, however: the Toronto gay village on Church Street is really in decline.
Some of the very decent restaurants have been replaced by dumpier, not-so-great diners, or are shuttered.
As for the bars, it's to be expected: warn-out regulars nursing drinks on bar stools during the day, loud and drunk young men, women and etc. during the night.
Classy it is not. However, more heeled gays may prefer Queen West for the classier gay scene.

reviews.title: Idenitity
text: This is the centre of the city's gay culture, but there is little here to necessarily identify it as such, unless you are there for the nightlife.  As such it is not really a site in itself, as it is mostly just a bunch of stores during the day.

reviews.title: Still a great place, but declining
text: Twenty years ago the "Gay Village" was the place to be in Toronto. It was overflowing with trendy, young men and women of all sexual persuasions, with very hip bars and restaurants, and stylish shops. Those days have gone. Today, several of the storefronts are papered over, and there has been a considerable turnover among the others. The retail outlets are not high end, selling to the hip and monied gay community. The daily inhabitants appear to be mostly middle-aged men and aging single women, both groups very often attached to small dogs. In the evenings, the bars still come alive, but much of the "cutting edge" of LGBTQ culture has moved west to Ossington Ave. If you want decent food and a grown-up, middle-aged atmosphere, Church Street is still a great place. If you want the latest in music and trends, go west, young man, go west.

reviews.title: Walk and enjoy
text: This is the gay area in Toronto, all streets, banks and shops have the gay flag in their logo or walls. Very nice to walk around.
